{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix = Sir | name = Ion Hamilton Benn | honorific-suffix = Bt CB DSO TD | image = | alt = | constituency_MP = [[Greenwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Greenwich]] | parliament = United Kingdom | majority = | predecessor = [[Richard Stephens Jackson]] | successor = [[George Hopwood Hume]] | term_start = January 1910 | term_end = November 1922 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1863|3|31|df=yes}} | birth_place = County Cork, Ireland | death_date = {{Death date and age|1961|8|12|1863|3|31|df=yes}} | death_place = Kensington, London | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | birthname = | citizenship = | nationality = British | party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] | otherparty = | spouse = {{marriage|Frances Charlotte Bridges|1885|1948}} (her death)
{{marriage|Katharine Winifred Grier|1950|1961}} (his death) | relations = | children = | parents = Reverend J. W. Benn
Maria Hamilton | residence = | alma_mater = [[Merchant Taylors' School, Northwood|Merchant Taylors' School]] | occupation = Company director | profession = | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | religion = | signature = | signature_alt = | nickname = | allegiance = [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] | branch = [[Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve]] | serviceyears = | rank = [[Captain (Royal Navy)|Captain]] | unit = [[Dover Patrol]] | commands = | battles = [[World War I]]
{{*}} [[Zeebrugge Raid]]
{{*}} [[First Ostend Raid]]
{{*}} [[Second Ostend Raid]] | awards = {{Plainlist| * [[Order of the Bath]] * [[Distinguished Service Order]] * [[Croix de guerre 1914–1918 (France)|Croix de Guerre]] (France) }} }} Captain '''Sir Ion Hamilton Benn, 1st Baronet''', [[Order of the Bath|CB]], [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]], [[Territorial Decoration|TD]] (31 March 1863 – 12 August 1961) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] politician and businessman. He was a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|member of parliament]] from 1910 to 1922.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Obituary: Captain Sir Ion Hamilton Benn. Public Life And The City |day_of_week=Monday |date=14 August 1961 |page_number=13 }} ==Early life, family and business career== Benn was born in [[County Cork]], [[Ireland]]. He was the third son of the Reverend J. W. Benn, [[Church of Ireland]] [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]] of [[Carrigaline]] and [[Douglas, County Cork|Douglas]], and his wife Maria (née Hamilton).{{cite web |url=http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whowaswho/U55123 |title=Benn, Captain Sir Ion Hamilton |date=December 2007 |work=[[Who Was Who]] |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |accessdate=4 September 2011}} He was educated at [[Merchant Taylors' School, Northwood|Merchant Taylors' School]] and then joined Price & Pierce Ltd, a leading [[timber]] firm. He later became a director and then [[chairman]]. In 1885 he married Frances Charlotte Bridges, with whom he had two children. ==Political career== In 1900, he was elected to [[Metropolitan Borough of Greenwich|Greenwich Borough Council]] and served as [[mayor]] from 1901 to 1902. He was a founder member of the [[Metropolitan Water Board (London)|Metropolitan Water Board]] in 1903. He was a [[Municipal Reform Party]] member of [[London County Council]] representing Greenwich from 1907 to 1910. At the [[United Kingdom general election, 1906|1906 general election]] he was chosen by the [[Tariff Reform League|Tariff Reform]] faction in the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] to stand against [[Hugh Cecil, 1st Baron Quickswood|Lord Hugh Cecil]] the sitting Conservative MP for [[Greenwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Greenwich]] who was in favour of [[free trade]]. While Benn succeeded in beating Cecil, the split in the Conservative vote allowed [[Richard Stephens Jackson]] of the [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal Party]] to take the seat.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The General Election |day_of_week=Tuesday |date=16 January 1906 |page_number=10 }} At the next [[United Kingdom general election, January 1910|general election in January 1910]] he was the sole Conservative candidate in the constituency and was elected to [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|parliament]]. In parliament, he was a leading opponent of [[Irish Home Rule]]. ==Military career== On 26 May 1906 he was appointed [[Honorary Colonel]] of the [[20th Battalion, London Regiment (Blackheath and Woolwich)|2nd Volunteer Battalion, Queen's Own Royal West Kent Regiment]],{{London Gazette |issue=27916 |date=25 May 1906 |page=3662 }} which on 1 April 1908 became the [[20th Battalion, London Regiment (Blackheath and Woolwich)]].{{London Gazette |issue=28181 |date=29 September 1908 |page=7018 |nolink=yes }} A long-time member of the [[Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve]], Benn saw active service in the [[First World War]], being commissioned into the [[Royal Naval Reserve]] with the [[temporary rank]] of lieutenant-commander on 12 October 1914,{{London Gazette |issue=28935 |date=13 October 1914 |page=8130 |nolink=yes }} and receiving promotion to temporary commander in the Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve on 10 April 1915.{{London Gazette |issue=29127 |date=13 April 1915 |page=3581 |nolink=yes }} For three years he was the commander of a flotilla of [[motor launch]]es in the [[Dover Patrol]],{{London Gazette |issue=30870 |date=27 August 1918 |pages=10083–10085 |supp= y |nolink=yes }} taking part in the [[Zeebrugge Raid]] and the [[First Ostend Raid|First]] and [[Second Ostend Raid]]s. He was [[Mentioned in Despatches]] three times, and on 20 July 1917 was appointed a Companion of the [[Distinguished Service Order]] in recognition of his services at Zeebrugge on the 11–12 May 1917, and at Ostend on 4–5 June 1917.{{London Gazette |issue=30194 |date=20 July 1917 |page=7423 |supp= y |nolink=yes }} He was also awarded the ''[[Croix de guerre 1914–1918 (France)|Croix de Guerre]]'' by France in recognition of his services at Zeebrugge and at Ostend on 22–23 April 1918,{{London Gazette |issue=30807 |date=19 July 1918 |page=8599 |supp= y |nolink=yes }} and on 28 August 1918 was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] (Military Division), in recognition of his distinguished services during the Second Ostend Raid.{{London Gazette |issue=30870 |date=27 August 1918 |page=10089 |supp= y |nolink=yes }} ==Post-war== Benn was created a [[baronet]] in the June [[1920 Birthday Honours]] for his political services.{{London Gazette |issue=31931 |date=4 June 1920 |page=6314 |supp= y |nolink=yes }}{{London Gazette |issue=32035 |date=31 August 1920 |page=8860 |nolink=yes }} He retired from parliament at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1922|1922 election]]. On 23 June 1925 Benn was made a knight of the [[Venerable Order of Saint John|Grand Priory of the Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem in England]],{{London Gazette |issue=33059 |date=23 June 1925 |page=4193 |nolink=yes }} and on 11 May 1926 received the [[Territorial Decoration]].{{London Gazette |issue=33161 |date=11 May 1926 |page=3145 |nolink=yes }} Benn served on the Executive Committee of the [[National Playing Fields Association]] from its inaugural meeting at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in July 1925.{{cite report |title=NPFA Annual Report |issue=1 |date=1925}} From 1937 he was chairman of the seamen's [[Dreadnought Hospital]] in Greenwich, and became its president in 1949, serving until 1962.{{cite web |url=http://www.seahospital.org.uk/pdf/SHS%20R&A%202006%20.pdf |title=Seamen’s Hospital Society Annual Review 2006 |work=seahospital.org.uk |accessdate=14 April 2014 }} Benn was once again a member of the London County Council from 1937 to 1946. He served on the [[Thames Conservancy Board]] from 1937 to 1946, and was a director of the [[Port of London Authority]] from its foundation in 1909 until February 1961, when he was 97. He remained active in business in the [[City of London]] until his death at the age of 98. Benn's first wife died in 1948. He married Katharine Winifred Grier of [[Montreal]], [[Canada]] in 1950, when he was aged 87. He died at his [[Kensington]] home in August 1961, aged 98.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Deaths |day_of_week=Monday |date=14 August 1961 |page_number=1 }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Hansard-contribs | captain-sir-ion-benn | Sir Ion Benn }} {{s-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Greenwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Greenwich]] | years = [[United Kingdom general election, January 1910|January 1910]] – [[United Kingdom general election, 1922|1922]] | before = [[Richard Jackson (Liberal politician)|Richard Jackson]] | after = [[George Hume (politician)|George Hume]] }} {{s-reg|uk-bt}} {{succession box | title = [[Benn baronets|Baronet]] (of Rollesby) | years = 1920 – 1961 | before = '''New Creation''' | after = [[Patrick Ion Hamilton Benn]] }} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Benn, Ion}} [[Category:1863 births]] [[Category:1961 deaths]] [[Category:Politicians from County Cork]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:Members of London County Council]] [[Category:Conservative Party (UK) MPs for English constituencies]] [[Category:UK MPs 1910]] [[Category:UK MPs 1910–18]] [[Category:UK MPs 1918–22]] [[Category:Royal Navy officers]] [[Category:Baronets in the Baronetage of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Companions of the Distinguished Service Order]] [[Category:Recipients of the Croix de Guerre 1914–1918 (France)]] [[Category:Royal Navy officers of World War I]] [[Category:Members of Greenwich Metropolitan Borough Council]] [[Category:Municipal Reform Party politicians]]

[[File:Port of Chiba.jpg|thumb|right|Port of Chiba with [[Mount Fuji]] in background]]
{{nihongo|'''Keiyō Industrial Zone'''|京葉工業地域|Keiyō Kōgyō Chiiki}},<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Japan |title=Keiyō Industrial Region |url=http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |accessdate=2012-12-19 |year=2012 |publisher=Netto Adobansusha |location=Tokyo |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070825113418/http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |archivedate=2007-08-25 |df= }}</ref> also known as the Keiyō Industrial Region, the Keiyō Industrial Area, or the Keiyō Industrial Belt, is an [[industrial region|industrial zone]] on the northeastern coast of [[Tokyo Bay]] that crosses 8 cities in [[Chiba Prefecture]], [[Japan]]. The zone spans from the western part of [[Urayasu, Chiba|Urayasu]] in the northeast to [[Futtsu, Chiba|Futtsu]] in the southeast of the region. The zone has no political or administrative status.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Encyclopædia Britannica | title = Keiyō Industrial Zone | url = http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/314276/Keiyō-Industrial-Zone | accessdate = 2012-12-19 | year = 2012 | publisher = Encyclopædia Britannica | location = Chicago, Ill.}}</ref>
==Etymology==
The name of the industrial zone is formed from two [[kanji]] characters. The first, {{linktext|京}}, means "[[capital city]]" and refers to Tokyo. The second, {{linktext|葉}}, meaning "[[leaf]]", is the second kanji in "Chiba" and refers to Chiba Prefecture, and the compound refers to the Tokyo-Chiba region.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Dijitaru daijisen |title=Keiyō |url=http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |accessdate=2012-03-26 |year=2012 |publisher=Shogakukan |location=Tokyo |language=ja |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070825113418/http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |archivedate=2007-08-25 |df= }}</ref>
==Geography==
The Keiyō Industrial Zone spans the coast of Tokyo Bay from Urayasu in the northeast, through [[Funabashi, Chiba|Funabashi]], [[Chiba, Chiba|Chiba City]], [[Kisarazu, Chiba|Kisarazu]], [[Kimitsu, Chiba|Kimitsu]], [[Ichihara, Chiba|Ichihara]], [[Sodegaura, Chiba|Sodegaura]], and ends in [[Futtsu, Chiba|Futtsu]] to the southeast. Numerous small rivers empty into the industrial region, and provide a source of water to support industry. They include the [[Edo River]], the [[Yōrō River]], and the [[Koito River]].
==History== [[File:Nippon Steel Kimitsu Works.jpg|thumb|left|Nippon Steel Kimitsu Works]] Before industrialization the Keiyō region was originally home to ''[[nori]]'' [[seaweed]] collection, the [[shellfish]] industry, mixed small-scale fishing and agricultural villages, and [[seaside resort|beach resorts]].<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Encyclopædia Britannica | title = Keiyō Industrial Zone | url = http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/314276/Keiyō-Industrial-Zone | accessdate = 2012-12-19 | year = 2012 | publisher = Encyclopædia Britannica | location = Chicago, Ill.}}</ref> The [[Keihin region]], spanning west from Tokyo to [[Yokohama, Kanagawa|Yokohama]], was developed after [[World War I]]. With the rapid development of the [[defense industry]] in Japan from the beginning of the [[Shōwa period]] in 1926, a plan for the [[decentralization]] of industry from the immediate Tokyo area was planned in 1935. The Keiyō Industrial Region was fully developed after [[World War II]]. Some [[land reclamation]] had been carried out in coastal areas of Tokyo Bay as part of the industrialization of Japan in the early 20th century. Reclaimed land areas replaced traditional fishing areas and supported small factories. The construction of the [[Kawasaki Steel Corporation|Kawasaki]] [[Kawasaki Steel Works|Steel Works]] in Chiba City in 1953 marked the beginning of the large-scale construction of [[heavy industry]] infrastructure in the industrial zone,<ref>{{Citation | last = Chiba-ken Kikakubu Kenminka | title = Chiba-ken hyakunen no ayumi | publisher = Chiba-ken | year = 1973 | pages = 38|language=ja}}</ref> and other industries soon followed. The [[deepwater port]]s of the Keiyō Industrial Zone were built starting in the 1950s. [[Thermal power]] [[Electric generator|generator]]s were built,<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Encyclopædia Britannica | title = Keiyō Industrial Zone | url = http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/314276/Keiyō-Industrial-Zone | accessdate = 2012-12-19 | year = 2012 | publisher = Encyclopædia Britannica | location = Chicago, Ill.}}</ref> and large tracts of land were reclaimed from the bay for expansion of the Keiyō region. Keiyō was significantly expanded in the 1960s. [[Heavy metal (chemistry)|Heavy metal]] and [[chemical industry|chemical production]] were among the highest in Japan by the 1970s.
==Industries==
The zone is a major base for the [[electric power generation]], [[petrochemical]], [[petroleum]], [[shipbuilding]], [[logistics]], [[shipping]], and [[steel]] industries.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Japan |title=Keiyō Industrial Region |url=http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |accessdate=2012-12-19 |year=2012 |publisher=Netto Adobansusha |location=Tokyo |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070825113418/http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |archivedate=2007-08-25 |df= }}</ref> The [[Port of Chiba]] is a major component to the Keiyō Industrial Region.
== Gallery == <gallery> File:Yōrō River and Port of Chiba 01.jpg|Yōrō River and Port of Chiba File:View from Chiba Port-Tower North.jpg|[[Chiba Port Tower]] </gallery>
== References ==
