{{Infobox film | name = The Go Getter | image = | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Busby Berkeley]] | producer = [[Hal B. Wallis]] (uncredited) | writer = [[Delmer Daves]] | based on = {{Based on|the short story "The Go-Getter"|[[Peter B. Kyne]]}} | starring = [[George Brent]]
[[Anita Louise]]
[[Charles Winninger]] | music = [[Bernhard Kaun]] | cinematography = [[Arthur Edeson]] (uncredited) | editing = [[William Holmes (film editor)|William Holmes]] | studio = [[Cosmopolitan Productions]] | distributor = [[Warner Bros.]] | released = {{film date|1937|5|22}} | runtime = 92 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Go Getter''''' is a 1937 film directed by [[Busby Berkeley]] and starring [[George Brent]], [[Anita Louise]], and [[Charles Winninger]]. A determined discharged US Navy veteran succeeds in the lumber business. ==Plot== When the US Navy rigid [[airship]] ''Macon'' is damaged in a storm and crashes into the water (as the real {{USS|Macon|ZRS-5|6}} did in 1935), helmsman Bill Austin stays with his commanding officer until the rest of the crew has gotten safely away. Bill loses a leg as a result of the crash and leaves the Navy. He goes looking for employment, but jobs are scarce in [[San Francisco]]. He tries a lumber company run by Lloyd Skinner, interrupting a meeting between Skinner and his fiancee Margaret Ricks. Skinner orders him to leave his office. Matt Peasely, head of a shipping firm in the same building, is more polite, but the answer is still the same. Undeterred, Bill seeks out Cappy Ricks, the retired founder of both companies. While waiting in the reception area, he encounters Margaret again. He assumes she is also a job seeker and makes a date with her, unaware she is Cappy's only offspring. She sees her father first, and asks him to give Bill a chance. Cappy, who is frustrated with the way Skinner and Peasely have been running the businesses he built up, is quite willing to countermand them. He and Skinner decide to give Bill the hardest task they can think of: selling a half million feet of unwanted [[Picea glauca|skunk spruce]] Cappy bought years ago as a favor to a friend. Not only does Bill sell all of the spruce, he also generates orders for all of the lumber the company has and more, all in a single business trip across the western United States, forcing Cappy to send him to Seattle to buy the shortfall from a hard-negotiating competitor. Meanwhile, Bill and Margaret fall in love. With his commission from his trip, he buys an engagement ring. When he tells Cappy of his plans, however, the widowed Cappy is adamantly opposed to losing Margaret's company. He and Skinner go ahead with the "blue vase" test, a test everybody has failed, including Skinner. Cappy telephones Bill and tells him he saw a vase he liked, but could not spare the time to purchase it. He gives Bill instructions to buy it whatever the cost and bring it to him at the railway station by eight o'clock. Cappy and Skinner have pre-arranged all sorts of obstacles to make the task impossible, but Bill overcomes them all, and by hocking Margaret's ring to help pay the $1000 price of the vase and persuading a Navy pilot friend (on his honeymoon night, no less) to fly him ahead of the already departed train, he succeeds. Cappy is so impressed, he offers Bill a promotion to manager of his [[Shanghai]] office. When Bill insists on marrying Margaret immediately so she can accompany him, Cappy does his best to stop him. He buys up all the staterooms in the ship Bill is to take, but Bill and Margaret get married and manage to sneak aboard the ship anyway. Then Cappy receives word that his men have gone on strike, and they trust and will only negotiate with Bill. Cappy sends him an urgent [[radiogram (message)|radiogram]]. When the captain of the ship refuses Bill's request to turn around, Bill jumps overboard. Margaret follows him, and the captain drops a lifeboat. Cappy finds them rowing back to land. Bill negotiates an end to the strike, and Cappy decides to send Skinner to Shanghai instead. For Cappy's sake, the couple agree to live in his mansion. ==Cast== {{div col}} * George Brent as Bill Austin * Anita Louise as Margaret Ricks * Charles Winninger as Cappy Ricks * [[John Eldredge (actor)|John Eldredge]] as Lloyd Skinner * [[Henry O'Neill]] as Commander Tisdale * [[Joseph Crehan]] as Karl Stone * [[Gordon Oliver]] as Luce * [[Eddie Acuff]] as Bob Blair * [[Willard Robertson]] as Matt Peasely * [[Pierre Watkin]] as Browne * [[Joan Valerie]] as Skinner's Secretary (as Helen Valkis) * [[Herbert Rawlinson]] as Lester * [[George Chandler]] as Business Card Printer * Helen Lowell as Mrs. Luce * [[Harry Beresford]] as M. M. Barker * [[Minerva Urecal]] as Cappy Ricks' Secretary * [[Mary Treen]] as Mrs. Blair {{div col end}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0028939|The Go Getter}} * {{tcmdb title|2227|The Go Getter}} {{Busby Berkeley}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Go Getter, The}} [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American business films]] [[Category:American romance films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:Films based on short fiction]] [[Category:Films directed by Busby Berkeley]] [[Category:Films set in San Francisco]] [[Category:1930s business films]]

{{Infobox person | name = Tomás Dolz de Espejo | image = [[File:Tomas_Dolz_de_Espejo.jpg|260px]] | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Tomás Dolz de Espejo | birth_date = 1879 | birth_place = [[Bayonne]] | death_date = 1974 | death_place = [[Madrid]] | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = landowner | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Carlism]], [[Falange Española Tradicionalista y de las Juntas de Ofensiva Nacional Sindicalista|FET]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }} '''Tomás Dolz de Espejo Andreu Muñoz Serrano y Duforq-Salinis, 5th Count of La Florida''' (1879-1974) was a Spanish politician and businessman. For some 30 years he campaigned within [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalism]] and [[Carlism]]. Periodically he was holding regional party leadership jobs, though nationwide he remained rather in the back row. He is best known as member of the first Junta Política and [[National Council of the Movement|Consejo Nacional]], executive bodies of the newly created [[Francoism|Francoist]] state party, [[Falange Española Tradicionalista y de las Juntas de Ofensiva Nacional Sindicalista|Falange Española Tradicionalista]].
==Family and youth== [[File:Albarracín - Casa de los Dolz de Espejo - Portada.jpg|thumb|160px|left|Dolz de Espejo house, [[Albarracín]]]] The Dolz lineage is related to Southern [[Aragón]]; its first representatives were noted in the late 12th century, once the successful [[Reconquista]] claimed [[Teruel]].<ref>Rocio Castellote Simón, ''El retablo de la Virgen del Pilar de la iglesia de San Bernardo abad de Gea de Albarracín'', Valencia 2016, p. 18</ref> The family was initially linked to [[Albarracín]],<ref>Tomás Alamán Artigot, ''Gea en el tiempo'', [in:] ''GeaDeAlbarracín'' service, available [http://www.geadealbarracin.com/historia.htm here]</ref> over time spreading to neighboring counties.<ref>more details are scattered across different volumes of ''Linajes de Aragón. Revista quincenal ilustrada'', see for instance Gregorio García Ciprés, ''Los Sánchez-Muñoz de Teruel'', [in:] ''Linajes de Aragón'' 01.05.12, pp. 137-141</ref> The Espejo lineage originated from Northern parts of [[Kingdom of Valencia]], resident in [[:es:Castelfabib|Castelfabib]].<ref>Manuel Fuertes de Gilbert Rojo, ''Albarracin: linajes y testimonios heraldicos'', [in:] José Antonio Salas Ausens (ed.), ''Tiempo de Derecho foral en el sur aragonés: los fueros de Teruel y Albarracín'', Zaragoza 2007, {{ISBN|9788489510814}}, pp. 55-106</ref> The two families intermarried in the early 17th century, giving rise to the Dolz de Espejo branch.<ref>Castellote Simón 2016, p. 18</ref> Many of its members made their names in history of Spain; Tomás’ great-grandfather, Pedro Federico Dolz de Espejo, was awarded the title of Conde de la Florida in 1789.<ref>detailed discussion in Fuertes de Gilbert Rojo 2007, pp. 55-106</ref>
His son, the 2nd Count and the grandfather of Tomás, [[Pedro Pablo Dolz de Espejo]],<ref>some services confuse different members of the family, compare ''Pedro Pablo Dolz de Espejo, 2. conde de la Florida'' entry, [in:] ''Geneallnet'' service, available [http://geneall.net/es/name/1824586/pedro-pablo-dolz-de-espejo-2-conde-de-la-florida/ here], or ''Compactgen'' service, available [http://compactgen.com/es/f/flo.htm here]. Even the canonical lecture of Traditionalist history confuses the family members; Ferrer refers to "Pedro Manuel Dolz de Espejo y Martinez Serrano", who allegedly died 1882 in Madrid, [[Melchor Ferrer Dalmau|Melchor Ferrer]], ''Historia del tradicionalismo español'', vol. 28/2, Sevilla 1959. p. 260</ref> distinguished himself during the [[Peninsular War|Napoleonic era]]. At the outbreak of the [[First Carlist War]] in 1833 he sided with the [[Infante Carlos, Count of Molina|legitimists]]; following defeat he went into exile and died in 1842 in [[Bordeaux]].<ref>''La Unión Católica'' 09.01.80, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1000189970&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> His son and Tomás’ father, [[Pedro Manuel Dolz de Espejo]] (1820-1879), as 3rd Count returned<ref>born in 1820 he left Spain as a teenager, accompanying his father into exile</ref> to Spain re-assuming family landholdings in Teruel.<ref>''La Unión Católica'' 09.01.80</ref> He joined the Carlist conspiracy too,<ref>in 1869 he was appointed comisario regio for Maestrazgo - Melchor Ferrer, ''Historia del tradicionalismo español'', vol. 23, Sevilla 1955, p. 31 and comisario for Valencia - Jordi Canal, ''El carlismo'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|8420639478}}, p. 159; in 1870 he became member of the claimant’s consejo provisional - Ferrer 1955, p. 120; in 1872 he was nominated to [[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|claimant’s]] Real Junta – Melchor Ferrer, ''Historia del tradicionalismo español'', vol. 24, Sevilla 1955, p. 22</ref> during [[Third Carlist War]] entrusted with economic issues; it was his signature present on banknotes, issued by the Carlists.<ref>''ABC'' 21.02.59, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/blanco.y.negro/1959/02/21/107.html here]</ref> He too went into exile, settling in [[Bayonne]]. He married<ref>in 1876; it is not clear whether the wedding took place in Spain or – which is more likely - already on exile</ref> a girl from another aristocratic Aragón family, María Andreu y Duforq-Salinis<ref>see ''María del Carmen Andreu y Dufourg-Salinis'' entry, [in:] ''Geneallnet'' service, available [http://geneall.net/es/name/1936455/maria-del-carmen-andreu-y-dufourg-salinis/ here]</ref> (1843<ref>Roberto Moreno y Mórrison, ''Continuación de los Titulos del Reino'', [in:] ''Revista de Historia y Genealogía Española'' 10-11 (1928), p. 885, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026680610&page=101 here]</ref>-1920<ref>''El Debate'' 10.02.20, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=2279126&presentacion=pagina here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 10.02.20, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000367914&page=3 here]</ref>).
Between 1876 and 1879 the couple had 3 children;<ref>''La Unión Católica'' 09.01.80</ref> Tomás was born in [[France]]<ref>''El Correo Español'' 23.09.17, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029778907&page=1 here]</ref> as the younger of two sons.<ref>''La Unión Católica'' 09.01.80</ref> It is not clear when the widow and half-orphans returned to Spain;<ref>a paternal uncle of Tomás, the younger brother of the late Pedro Manuel, also a Carlist supporter Federico Dolz de Espejo, stayed on exile in Saint-Jean-de-Luz until his death in 1886, ''Diario de Teruel'' 12.02.86, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=2302422&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> she is first noted back in the family palace in Teruel<ref>at Calle de los Amantes</ref> in 1888.<ref>''El Correo de Teruel'' 30.12.88, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=2301169&presentacion=pagina here], see also ''Eco de Teruel'' 28.05.93, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=1098702&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> None of the sources consulted provides information on early years of Tomás, except that he was brought up in "escuela de la lealtad y sacrificio". It is neither clear where he received his education; because he was later referred to as "engineer" he probably studied technology,<ref>Santiago Olives Canals, Stephen Taylor, ''Who's who in Spain'', vol. 1, Madrid 1963, p. 260</ref> possibly in [[Madrid]].<ref>in 1902 a certain "Tomas Dolz" is noted as setting up – together with individuals who later became well known - a Madrid football club named The-Sport-Foot-Ball-Club, ''El Cardo'' 30.11.02, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0028153279&page=8 here]</ref> At unspecified time in the 1900s he engaged in construction; in 1911 he was noted as manager of a Madrid-based company, La Constructora.<ref>''Revista Católica de Cuestiones Sociales'' 201 (1911), p. 193, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002659947&page=29 here]; he was also reported otherwise engaged in construction business, ''El Correo Español'' 12.08.12, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029769878&page=3 here], and ''Arquitectura'' 241 (1912), p. 255, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004947271&page=53 here]</ref> In 1912 he was referred to as "propietario";<ref>''Revista Católica de Cuestiones Sociales'' 201 (1911)</ref> he took over the family business in 1913, following premature and childless death of his older brother, the 4th Count;<ref>Pedro Dolz de Espejo Andreu Muñoz Serrano y Duforq-Salinis (1877-1913); though his father died in 1879, he was formally recognized as the 4th conde in 1903, compare ''Diario de Teruel'' 04.01.03, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=2301726&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> he also inherited the title.<ref>''ABC'' 19.03.12, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1912/03/19/009.html here], ''El Mercantil'' 17.01.14, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2303035&presentacion=pagina here]; though his brother died in 1913, Tomás Dolz was formally recognized as the 5th count in 1917, ''Revista de historia y de genealogía española'' 11 (1916), p. 527, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026675175&page=39 here]</ref> [[File:Brick Building, Barrio de Salamanca Madrid, Spain.JPG|thumb|Conde de Aranda street, [[Madrid]]]] In 1912<ref>''ABC'' 19.03.12, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1912/03/19/009.html here]</ref> Tomás Dolz married María de la Estrella González de la Riva Vidiella (1882<ref>''ABC'' 27.03.89, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1989/03/27/091.html here]; another source claims her birth date was 1881, Moreno y Mórrison 1928, p. 885</ref>-1989<ref>''ABC'' 27.03.89</ref>), daughter to teniente coronel de artillería 9th [[:es:Marquesado de Villa Alcázar|Marques de Villa Alcázar]].<ref>as a teenager she moved with her parents to Madrid. One source claims she was born in Salamanca, see Moreno y Mórrison 1928, p. 885; another one sort of suggests she might have been born in Cádiz, compare ''Francisco González de la Riva y Vidiella, Marqués de Villa Alcázar'', [in:] ''Ruralmedia'' service, available [http://ruralmedia.eu/marques-de-villa-alcazar/ here]</ref> The couple settled in Madrid at Conde Aranda;<ref>they lived at Conde de Aranda 20, Moreno y Mórrison 1928, p. 885</ref> they had 3 children, born between 1913 and 1914. None of them became a public figure, though the only son, [[Carlos Dolz de Espejo y González de la Riva]] (1913-2013), an [[air force]] general,<ref>he rose to segundo jefe of the Air Force general staff, then nominated Jefe de la Zona Aérea de Canarias, ''BOE'' 25.05.76, available [https://www.boe.es/boe/dias/1976/05/25/pdfs/A10066-10066.pdf here], also ''ABC'' 25.11.72, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1972/11/25/065.html here]</ref> briefly gained media attention in relation to the most famous Spanish [[UFO]] incident of 1976.<ref>named "ovni de Galdar", compare himself speaking on the event in 1996, ''YouTube'' service, available [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rmZTI8i6SlM here]</ref> A younger daughter, María,<ref>there were two daughters, Carmen (1914-2008) and María (1914-2007), compare ''ABC'' 26.01.74, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1974/01/26/083.html here], ''ABC'' 19.12.07, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2007/12/19/067.html here], and ''ABC'' 05.10.08, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2008/10/05/062.html here]</ref> married Antonio Galbis Loriga, Conde de Morphy, general de artillería and [[Adjutant|ayudante honoríficio]] to [[Francisco Franco|Franco]].<ref>''ABC'' 15.03.03, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2003/03/15/077.html here]</ref> Among numerous grandchildren of Tomás and María, the best known ones are Carlos Dolz de Espejo y Arrospide, businessman and the 7th Conde de la Florida,<ref>compare ''Dolz De Espejo Arrospide Carlos'' entry, [in:] ''Empresia'' service, available [http://www.empresia.es/persona/dolz-de-espejo-arrospide-carlos/ here]</ref> and Alfonso Galbis Dolz de Espejo, a painter.<ref>compare his works, available [http://www.galeriaeboli.com/Eboli_Artistas41.htm here]</ref>
==Early political career (until 1919)== [[File:Ramon Nocedal.JPG|thumb|160px|left|[[Ramón Nocedal Romea|Ramón Nocedal]]]] With two generations of ancestors serving the legitimist cause Dolz seemed poised to follow suit, especially that also his mother came from a Traditionalist family.<ref>daughter of marqués de Ballestar, Moreno y Mórrison 1928, p. 885. The Ballestars supported the Carlists since the First Carlist War, Alfonso Bullón de Mendoza Gómez de Valugera, ''La nobleza carlista'', [in:] ''Nobleza y sociedad en la España moderna'' 2 (1997), p. 102</ref> However, during his youth Traditionalism was divided into mainstream Carlists and the breakaway [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrists]]. His brother, only 2 years senior, sided with the rebels; as a 16-year-old in 1893 he publicly voiced support for the [[Ramón Nocedal Romea|Nocedalistas]].<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 14.03.93, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000170527&page=1 here]</ref> In course of the 1890s Pedro Dolz de Espejo grew in the Integrist structures,<ref>''El Ancora'' 25.09.97, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2252841&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> in 1900 rising to president of the [[Valencia (province)|Valencian]] Junta Provincial<ref>''El estandarte católico'' 14.09.00, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1025350&presentacion=pagina here], ''La correspondencia de Valencia'' 16.04.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1000238926&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and in 1907 entering the executive of [[Valencia (autonomous community)|Valencian]] Junta Regional.<ref>rising to its vice-president, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 12.06.06, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000260348&page=1 here], ''El Ebro'' 15.06.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=4&path=1026881&forma=&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> However, none of the sources consulted confirms (or denies) that Tomás followed his older brother; until the early 1910s he is not recorded as engaged in politics.
Dolz was first noted in political milieu<ref>apart from non-political incidents, some of them awkward; in 1911 he engaged in a brawl, related to his borrowing and breaking of a camera, compare ''La Mañana'' 19.08.11, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026277183&page=4 here]</ref> in 1911; he demonstrated support to Traditionalist deputies from both the Integrist and [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Jaimist]] minorities, who in the [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]] in vain tried to block [[:es:Ley del Candado|Ley del Candado]].<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 06.01.11, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000294447&page=1 here]</ref> In 1912 he was admitted to [[:es:Real Maestranza de Caballería de Zaragoza|Real Maestranza de Caballeria de Zaragoza]], a theoretically non-political but in fact highly conservative aristocratic organization.<ref>''Anuario de la nobleza de España'' 1911, p. 587, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=607&path=1000179115&forma=&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Following death of his older brother he became a somewhat prestigious figure in the Teruel realm and as such decided to join the electoral race: in [[Spanish general election, 1914|1914]] he ran to the Cortes from [[Mora de Rubielos]], a district in the [[Teruel (province)|Teruel province]]; it was also the first time he declared himself a Jaimista, member of Carlist branch supporting the claim of [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]].<ref>''Diario de Valencia'' 04.03.14, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1000187325&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> The attempt proved premature and he lost pathetically, gaining 10 times fewer votes than a victorious candidate.<ref>''Diario Turolense'' 13.10.14, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=2300504&presentacion=pagina here], ''El mercantil'' 09.03.14, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2303225&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Following the defeat Florida is never confirmed to have renewed his bid for the parliament.
In the mid-1910s Florida, already referred to in the press as "rico propietario", was already fully engaged in the Jaimista structures. In 1915 he was rumored to be running in the [[Spanish general election, 1916|Cortes elections of the following year]] from the [[Latina (Madrid)|Madrid Latina district]];<ref>''Diario Turolense'' 07.10.15, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2301264&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> the news eventually proved false, though in 1916 he was busy mounting an electoral alliance which would include even the Traditionalist arch-enemies, the [[Liberal Party (Spain, 1880)|Liberals]].<ref>''El Cronista de Teruel'' 21.03.16, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=2304527&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In 1917 he worked to seal an electoral union of the Jaimists, the Integrists, the [[Antonio Maura|Maurists]] and independent candidates, to be fielded in the [[Spanish general election, 1918|forthcoming electoral campaign]].<ref>''La Cruz'' 21.11.17, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3049708&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> He rose to first secretary of the Madrid municipal Jaimist organization,<ref>''ABC'' 06.05.17, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1917/05/06/018.html here]</ref> in 1918 growing to its jefe<ref>''El Correo Español'' 23.09.17, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029778907&page=1 here]</ref> and soon also jefe of the provincial Madrid structures,<ref>''El Porvenir'' 17.05.18, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2150876&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> though in general remained a back-row party figure.<ref>Florida is not a single time mentioned in an extensive study dealing with Carlist political history of the late 19th and early 20th history, see Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845-1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis], Madrid 2012</ref> [[File:Vázquez de Mella 3.jpg|thumb|[[Juan Vázquez de Mella|de Mella]] speaking, 1916]] Though he seemed perfectly loyal to Don Jaime,<ref>e.g. in 1918 he entertained Infanta Beatriz, sister of the claimant Don Jaime, ''El Debate'' 23.06.18, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=2279721&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> in the new internal conflict within Carlism Florida tended rather to side with its key theorist, [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]]. This was demonstrated not only by [[Mellismo|Mellista]]-typical penchant for right-wing alliances,<ref>one scholar defined Mellismo as a political strategy, aiming at building ultra-Right alliances centred around Traditionalism though with dynastic issues sidetracked or even ignored, Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, ''El cisma mellista. Historia de una ambición política'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863820}}</ref> but also by advocating neutralist stand in the [[First World War|Great War]], a strategy intended to counter pro-[[Entente Cordiale|Entente]] feelings and effectively supporting the [[Central Powers]].<ref>1916 co-organized "conferencia neutralista", ''Heraldo Militar'' 28.10.16, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003417319&page=1 here]</ref> Florida was not among chief protagonists of the strife and remained in the background; however, when in 1919 Vázquez de Mella broke away and set up his own party, Dolz de Espejo decided to join him.
==Rebellious Mellista and reconciled Carlista (1919-1936)== [[File:1926 Buick Model 20-26 Coach, National Road Transport Hall of Fame, 2015.JPG|thumb|left|[[Buick]] model, 1926]] In 1920 Florida joined a 3-member Mellista [[New Castile (Spain)|Castilla La Nueva]] executive;<ref>''El norte'' 10.06.20, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3066975&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> in 1921 he assumed the position of Jefe Provincial in [[Madrid (province)|Madrid]]<ref>''El Debate'' 12.07.21, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=4&path=2282125&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and honorary president of the Madrid branch of the party youth, Juventud Católica Tradicionalista.<ref>the president was Martin Asúa, with vice-presidency falling to Ricardo Oreja, ''La Reconquista'' 05.11.21, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=1015391&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Reported as engaged in a variety of initiatives – setting up new cinemas in Madrid,<ref>in 1919, Angel Caldito, ''Los primeros estudios de cine en Madrid - Atlándita Cinematográfica'', [in:] ''Historias matritenses'' 04.12.08, available [http://historias-matritenses.blogspot.com/2008/12/los-primeros-estudios-de-cine-en-madrid.html here]</ref> collecting money for religious purposes,<ref>1920 engaging in erecting of a monument to [[Our Lady of the Pillar|Virgen del Pilar]] in [[Lourdes]], ''La Independencia'' 10.09.20, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2125930&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> donating and organizing donations to [[Rif War|army operations in Morocco]],<ref>in 1921 he donated 500 ptas to a committee, collecting money with intention to buy an aircraft; named "Teruel", it was to be given to the army to engage in combat in Morocco, ''La Provincia'' 11.08.21, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=2302008&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> taking part in Catholic ceremonies,<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 11.03.22, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=5&path=7135200&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> supporting sports<ref>''El Debate'' 03.09.23, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=6&path=2285167&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>- he was not, however, noted as busy building the party structures.<ref>Florida is not mentioned a single time in a monographical volume discussing the Mellista breakup, compare Andrés Martín 2000</ref> In 1922 he attended a general Mellista assembly, taking place in [[Zaragoza]] and supposed to finalize buildup of the new party.<ref>''El norte'' 17.10.22, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=3065841&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> The assembly launched Comité Directivo of the newly formed [[Partido Tradicionalista (Mellista party)|Partido Tradicionalista]];<ref>''La Reconquista'' 04.11.22, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1015457&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Florida was one of its 3 members.<ref>along with Marqués de Valdespina and Teodoro Más, ''El Debate'' 21.12.22, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=2283555&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> He was also confirmed as the Madrid Jefe Provincial, temporarily given command of "provincias del Centro, Sur y Oeste de España".<ref>''El Norte'' 07.11.22, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=3065924&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> The Mellista project hardly took off the ground when the 1923 coup of [[Miguel Primo de Rivera]] banned all political parties in the country.
Florida withdrew to privacy, in public noted for [[Charity (practice)|charity]]<ref>''Teruel'' 07.08.28, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=2305083&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and glamour of aristocratic societé.<ref>''La Cruz'' 22.04.28, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3050345&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Resident of Madrid, he was spending strings at his La Florida property<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 29.06.21, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=5&path=7144093&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> in Teruel<ref>''La Provincia'' 13.08.21, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=2302017&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and in estates in Valencia. Fascinated by cars he managed a [[Autódromo de Sitges-Terramar|Sitges circuit]],<ref>''El Debate'' 03.09.23, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=6&path=2285167&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> excelled in [[Royal Automobile Club of Spain|Real Automovil Club]]<ref>and probably interfacing with Alfonso XIII, ''El Debate'' 24.04.22, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=6&path=2284095&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and co-ran a tourist review;<ref>''El defensor de Córdoba'' 16.01.26, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=5008722&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> owner of a new Buick,<ref>''El Iris'' 14.07.26, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=1000217046&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> he was fined for excessive driving<ref>''Teruel'' 23.07.28, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=2305054&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> until his car was stolen.<ref>from the street in front of his house, ''ABC'' 22.11.29, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1929/11/22/032.html here]</ref> Excluding landholding properties, he lived off a number of enterprises; apart from construction company he was president of Sociedad Española de Talcos<ref>''ABC'' 21.05.26, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1926/05/21/033.html here]</ref> and Compañia de Seguros Omnia.<ref>''ABC'' 29.05.32, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1932/05/29/019.html here]</ref> During [[:es:Dictablanda del general Dámaso Berenguer|dictablanda]] Dolz renewed political endeavors. In May 1930 he was received by [[Alfonso XIII]].<ref>it is not known what was the purpose of the meeting, ''ABC'' 09.05.30, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1930/05/09/021.html here]</ref> Against the rising Republican tide he stood on monarchist ground, cultivating old-style patriotism.<ref>he demanded firm line on dissenting groupings; in 1930 he signed a letter demanding stop to governmental subsidies to Ateneo de Madrid, accused of cultivating anti-patriotic threads, ''ABC'' 03.12.30, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1930/12/03/021.html here]</ref> Having joined [[:es:Unión Monárquica Nacional|Unión Monárquica Nacional]], in April 1931 he ran on its ticket in elections for the Madrid [[ayuntamiento]].<ref>result is not known; presumably he lost, ''El Adelanto'' 11.03.31, [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=5&path=1000352465&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumb|Carlist standard]] Upon declaration of the [[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] Florida tried to transfer his capital abroad.<ref>''El Telegrama del Rif'' 04.06.31, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=1000176172&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Apprehended by the customs service he was detained and possibly suffered forfeiture of some of the assets smuggled.<ref>''Las Provincias'' 30.05.31, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=10&path=1000319232&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> At unspecified time he returned to Carlist loyalty by entering [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]], which in 1932 re-joined the former Jaimistas, Integristas and Mellistas. In 1933 he was appointed its Jefe Regional of Castilla La Nueva.<ref>''Pensamiento Alaves'' 12.08.33, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=6&path=1000032204&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Despite holding a theoretically prestigious position, Florida did not seem particularly active; he was seldom recorded as speaking at party meetings<ref>though at times he did, compare ''Tradición'' 15.01.33, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=27&path=1000208691&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and historians almost do not mention his name when discussing Carlist activities during the Republic.<ref>1935 he co-founded a company Editorial Católica Gráfica, called up to issue a Madrid Catholic review ''Esto''; it is not clear whether this was part of the Carlist propaganda efforts, ''La Gaceta de Tenerife'' 13.02.35, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=5049194&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> It is not clear what his position was on controversial question of alliances with other monarchist and Right-wing groupings or on internal leadership rivalry between [[Tomas Dominguez Arevalo|Conde de Rodezno]] and [[Manuel Fal Conde|Manuel Fal]]. In 1935 the latter triggered his nomination to Junta de Hacienda,<ref>Melchor Ferrer, ''Historia del tradicionalismo español'' vol. 30/2, Sevilla 1979, p. 57, Robert Vallverdú i Martí, ''El carlisme català durant la Segona República Espanyola 1931-1936'', Barcelona 2008, {{ISBN|9788478260805}}, p. 276</ref> a body entrusted with organizing funds for the Comunión.
==Towards political climax (1936-1937)== [[File:Tropas del bando nacional (14 de 16) - Fondo Marín-Kutxa Fototeka.jpg|left|thumb|[[requetés]] (1936)]] It is not clear whether Florida was engaged in Carlist preparations to the [[Spanish coup of July 1936|July 1936 coup]]; in particular there is no information whether he opted for unconditional alliance with the military or rather for negotiating terms and conditions.<ref>Mercedes Peñalba Sotorrío, ''Entre la boina roja y la camisa azul'', Estella 2013, {{ISBN|9788423533657}}, p. 18</ref> It is neither known where he was during the first days of the fighting. Later Francoist propaganda claimed that from the onset Florida acted as member of Junta Carlista de Guerra del Reino de León;<ref>''El Progreso'' 29.04.37, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3103206&presentacion=pagina here], ''Heraldo de Zamora'' 27.03.37, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=2265890&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> the first confirmed information is that in September he emerged in [[Ciudad Rodrigo]], busy organizing [[Requeté]];<ref>''Miróbriga'' 20.09.36, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=1000166257&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> in October his [[León (historical region)|León]] efforts gained him a letter of thanks from the new Carlist regent, [[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Don Javier]].<ref>''Heraldo de Zamora'' 14.10.36, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=2257433&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Though he is not listed as member of the national Carlist wartime executive, Junta Nacional Carlista de Guerra,<ref>Florida is not listed among members of the Junta and heads of its agencies, compare Ricardo Ollaquindia Aguirre, ''La Oficina de Prensa y Propaganda Carlista de Pamplona al comienzo de la guerra de 1936'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 56 (1995), pp. 485-6</ref> residing in [[Salamanca]] he started to take part in meetings of the Comunión leaders. For reasons which are not entirely clear his position grew; perhaps as a host Florida presided over a Carlist emergency meeting of December 1936, called to deal with Franco’s demand that Fal Conde leaves Spain.<ref>Jaime del Burgo Torres, ''Un episodio poco conocido de la guerra civil española. La Real Academia Militar de Requetés y el destierro de Fal Conde'', [in:] ''Principe de Viana'' 196 (1992), p. 496</ref> It is not clear what position he took; some historians discussing the day refer to him as "Rodezno’s ally", which suggests that Florida proposed that the ultimatum be accepted.<ref>Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 2008, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}, p. 277</ref> [[File:Francisco Franco 1930.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Francisco Franco]] during the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]]]] Starting early 1937 the Carlists were facing a prospect of forced amalgamation into a state party; the claimant and the Falcondistas opted for intransigence, Rodezno and the [[Navarre]]se opted for negotiations. Florida was present at a February meeting in [[Insua]] and sided with the Rodeznistas,<ref>Robert Vallverdú i Martí, ''La metamorfosi del carlisme català: del "Déu, Pàtria i Rei" a l'Assamblea de Catalunya (1936-1975)'', Barcelona 2014, {{ISBN|9788498837261}}, p. 46</ref> position maintained also in March.<ref>in March 1937 Consejo de la Tradicióñ decided to send a delegation to Franco informing him that Junta Nacional resigned and could be re-appointed according to his will; the envoys were Martinez Berasain, Marcelino Ulibarri and José María García Verde, Florida was not mentioned, Peñalba Sotorrío 2013, pp. 42, 126</ref> In early April he took part in a meeting of a somewhat rebellious Navarrese Junta Central; it adopted a Franco-addressed proposal suggesting a directorio, composed of Carlists, [[Falange Española de las JONS|Falangists]] and caudillo’s appointees.<ref>the meeting took place on April 4, 1937. The 12-member directorio was to composed of 3 Carlists, 3 Falangists and 6 appointees of Franco, Juan Carlos Peñas Bernaldo de Quirós, ''El Carlismo, la República y la Guerra Civil (1936-1937). De la conspiración a la unificación'', Madrid 1996, {{ISBN|9788487863523}}, p. 262. It does not seem that at the time Florida took the unification threat very seriously, as on April 8, 1937 he was appointed president of jury to examin proposals for AET logotypes, ''Pensamiento Alaves'' 08.04.37, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=1000032217&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In mid-April he was one of 4 Carlists summoned to [[Burgos]]; generalísimo informed them about forthcoming political unification.<ref>apart from Florida, they were Rodezno, Ulíbarri and Martínez Berasain, Peñas Bernaldo 1996, p. 270</ref> It is not clear why he was picked up by Franco; some suggest that Florida was among most "conspicuous" Carlists because of his Requeté recruitment activities.<ref>"con cargo preeminente en la dirección del Requeté", Maximiliano García Venero, ''Historia de la unificación'', Madrid 1970, p. 96. This argument does not seem convincing, since the man formally responsible for Requeté, [[Jose Luis Zamanillo Gonzalez-Camino|Jose Luis Zamanillo]], was actually ignored by the Franco headquarters. As to Rodezno, it seems that he and his entourage considered unification sort of a loose general alliance; he ensured his fellow partymen that unification means monarchy, regionalism and Catholicism. Some scholars are not sure whether Florida took part in the meeting, Blinkhorn 2008, pp. 288, 360</ref>
At that time Franco and his aides were already considering personal composition of executive of the state party just to be announced. Florida was not among the Carlists initially marked; presented by Franco with shortlisted candidates,<ref>there were 3 Carlists on the original list of candidates: Conde de Rodezno, Marcelino Ulibarri and Luis Arellano, Peñalba Sotorrío 2013, p. 56</ref> Rodezno suggested that [[Marcelino Ulibarri]] is dropped and one more seat is reserved for the Carlists, coming with the names of Florida and [[José María Mazón]].<ref>Peñalba Sotorrío 2013, p. 56</ref> The proposal was accepted and on April 22 Dolz found himself among 4 Carlists nominated to a 10-member<ref>some scholars say there were 9 members, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 291</ref> "Secretariado o Junta Política"<ref>''Boletin Oficial de la Provincia de Soría'' 28.04.37, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=3027541&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> of Falange Española Tradicionalista.<ref>Peñalba Sotorrío 2013, p. 53</ref> Of all its members he was perhaps the least-known one; among press-published short notes about the appointees, his was the shortest one.<ref>''El Progreso'' 29.04.37, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3103206&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> [[:es:Decreto de Unificación|Terms of unification]] greatly disappointed many Carlists, including some of the Junta appointees;<ref>following publication of the Unification Decree some Carlists - Rodezno, Arellano, Ortigosa, Berasain - disgusted with its terms, visited Franco to voice their opinion; Florida was not among them, Peñalba Sotorrío 2013, p. 54</ref> the regent was furious. In June the Carlist junteros asked him to authorize their presence in the Junta, but to no avail;<ref>Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis in Historia Contemporanea, Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Valencia 2009 , p. 45</ref> later on all were expulsed from Comunión for breach of loyalty.<ref>some scholars claim they were expulsed on July 18, 1937 - Ana Marín Fidaldo, Manuel M. Burgueño, ''In memoriam. Manuel J. Fal Conde (1894-1975)'', Sevilla 1980, p. 45; some claim the correct date is December 3, 1937, Garcia Venero 1970, p. 109</ref>
==Executive or figurehead (1937-1939)== [[File:Bandera FE JONS.png|thumbnail|left|Falangist standard]] Frustrated by lack of the Falangist give and take in the Junta, some Carlists complained to Franco; the result were October 1937 nominations to another party body, a 50-member Consejo Nacional.<ref>''Boletin Oficial de la Provincia de Soría'' 26.10.37, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3028380&presentacion=pagina here], César Alcalá, ''D. Mauricio de Sivatte. Una biografía política (1901-1980)'', Barcelona 2001, {{ISBN|8493109797}}, p. 135</ref> Florida found himself among 12 Carlist nominees<ref>the nominees were not listed alphabetically, but in a specific order; Florida was among the last Carlists ranked. The sequence was as follows: 2. Rodezno, 6. [[Esteban de Bilbao Eguía|Bilbao]], 8. Muñoz Aguilar, 12. [[Joaquin Baleztena Ascarate|Baleztena]], 14. [[María Rosa Urraca Pastor|Urraca]], 17. [[Jose Maria Valiente Soriano|Valiente]], 23. Fal, 27. [[Jose Luis de Oriol y Uriguen|Oriol]], 29. Mazón, 32. Florida, 47. Arellano, 49. Toledo</ref> and was already firmly mounted among highest-positioned civilians of the Francoist Spain, sitting in two bodies directing the only political organization allowed in the state.<ref>none of the sources consulted provided any insight into a meteoric rise of Florida; from a local Carlist jefe, inactive and with no particular skills demonstrated so far, he turned into one of the highest-positioned civilians in the Francoist state</ref> However, many historians agree that both executive structures were rather decorative and that the entire party was at that stage a nascent structure, called into being to ensure that power stays with Franco and yet to acquire its later dynamics.<ref>compare Stanley G. Payne, ''Fascism in Spain'', Madison 1999, {{ISBN|9780299165642}}, especially chapters ''Francisco Franco and the formation of the Falange Española Tradicionalista'', pp. 239-272, and ''The FET during the Civil War'', pp. 273-39</ref> Moreover, the Carlists were enraged to find that what they supposed to be an organization they could control or at least influence was increasingly turning into a new version of Falange, with syndicalist blue-shirts systematically gaining the upper hand. Following unification Carlist rank-and-file started to bombard their leaders in Junta and in Consejo with complaints about getting sidetracked, asking for support. As recipient of these notes and phone calls Florida is recorded as pledging support; it is not clear whether he indeed intervened, though it is clear that nothing changed.<ref>José Antonio Parejo Fernández, ''Falangistas y requetés: historia de una absorción violenta'', [in:] María Encarna Nicolás Marín, Carmen González Martínez (eds.), ''Ayeres en discusión: temas clave de Historia Contemporánea'', Madrid 2008, {{ISBN|9788483717721}}, pp. 12-14, 16</ref> [[File:Entrevista entre Franco y el conde Ciano en San Sebastián en julio de 1939.jpg|thumb|160px|Francoism, 1939]] Throughout most of the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] in public Florida maintained a loyal Francoist stand.<ref>apparently he remained also on very good terms with the military of the Burgos headquarters, as he was in position to issue recommendations regarding handling of foreign vounteers; it was thanks to his support that in August 1937 colonel [[Antonio Barroso y Sánchez-Guerra]] directed a certain Andre Radzivill, referred to as "Principe de Estado de Ucraina (Polonia Rusa)", to enlist to the 6. Navarrese Brigade, Jan Stanisław Ciechanowski, ''Polscy ochotnicy po stronie narodowej'', [in:] Jan Kieniewicz (ed.), ''Studia polsko-hiszpańskie. Wiek XX'', Warszawa 2004, {{ISBN|8392018028}}, p. 143</ref> In newspapers he was quoted arguing in favor of the unification; according to him both Carlism and Falange were anti-democratic, anti-Liberal, anti-parliamentarian and Catholic, he claimed also that both supported monarchist solution, to be implemented in the future.<ref>''El Diario Palentino'' 28.02.38, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=4&path=2192141&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Apparently he also tried to cultivate the Traditionalist format as much as he could, with some other FET executives attending sermons honoring Carlist kings [[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Carlos VII]]<ref>''Azul'' 19.11.39, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=10&path=2003792&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and [[Alfonso Carlos, Duke of San Jaime|Alfonso Carlos]]<ref>''Heraldo de Zamora'' 28.09.39, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=4&path=1000116311&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> or taking part in annual Carlist feast dedicated to Mártires de la Tradición, initially observed by the state party. On the other hand, he did not refrain from attending new-style events, like banquets in the [[Nazi]] headquarters in Salamanca.<ref>''La Gaceta de Tenerife'' 30.11.37, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=5048112&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In 1938 he acted as FET Jefe Provincial in [[Salamanca (province)|Salamanca]],<ref>''Heraldo de Zamora'' 28.03.38, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=4&path=2261949&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> typically one of the 3 most important civilian positions in every province;<ref>the other two were gobernador civil and alcalde of the province capital, Andreu Ginés i Sànchez, ''La instauració del franquisme al País Valencià'' [PhD thesis Universitat Pompeu Fabra], Barcelona 2008, p. 141</ref> it is not clear what exact dates of his term were.
Florida’s career at the top of the Francoist political strata came to the end in late summer of 1939. As late as in August he was still reported taking part in public events as consejero nacional,<ref>''El Progreso'' 13.07.39, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=3103656&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> but this changed in September; he did not find himself among appointees to the II Consejo Nacional and starting 1940 he was reported in the press simply as "Conde de la Florida".<ref>''ABC'' 12.03.40, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1940/03/12/012.html here]</ref> None of the sources consulted offers any insight into his departure from the party executive, and specifically whether it was a fall from grace or a conscious decision to withdraw. It could have been resignation following disappointment with the syndicalist format of the new party; it could have been marginalization suffered as a result of an internal conflict, as it happened with [[Joaquín Bau]], another Carlist sidetracked by [[Ramón Serrano Suñer]],<ref>Joaquín Monserrat Cavaller, ''Joaquín Bau Nolla y la restauración de la Monarquía'', Madrid 2001, {{ISBN|8487863949}}, p. 184</ref> especially that Florida publicly kept declaring inevitable restoration of the monarchy.<ref>''El Diario Palentino'' 28.02.38, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=4&path=2192141&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
==Political retirement and long senility (after 1939)== [[File:RUMHE_logotype.jpg|thumb|left|RUMHE logotype]] No longer in the top political flight, in the early 1940s Florida was still present in public life, e.g. taking part in Traditionalism-flavored feasts attended by some FET heavyweights.<ref>''El Progreso'' 12.03.40, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=4&path=3104332&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In 1942 he was not appointed to the III Consejo Nacional<ref>''ABC'' 24.11.42, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1942/11/24/007.html here]</ref> and his political career seemed definitely over. This might not have been exactly the case, as in 1944 he was reported among governmental officials, namely noted as subsecretario de industria.<ref>''Imperio'' 27.02.44, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1000119252&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> This was, however, definitely the last of his Francoist episodes; afterwards he was no longer mentioned related either to the party or to the government. He did not accept an olive branch from Carlism; in 1942 Fal declared that all those stained by Falangism might be re-admitted given they abandon their state party links; the offer explicitly excluded from the scheme some of the leaders, but Florida was not among them.<ref>Peñalba Sotorrío 2013, p. 143</ref> In the late 1940s he ventured to publicly demonstrate support for [[Ricardo Oreja]], his old-time fellow Mellista, when the latter succeeded in Madrid municipal elections.<ref>''ABC'' 22.02.49, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1949/02/22/016.html here]</ref> [[File:Vertrek van Spaanse Troonpretendent Don Juan de Bourbon. Links de Hertog van Bae, Bestanddeelnr 910-8167.jpg|thumb|160px|Alfonsist claimant [[Infante Juan, Count of Barcelona|Juan de Borbón y Battenberg]] (right), 1959]] Though already at the retirement age, Florida remained active in a number of enterprises, mostly related to mineral resources and dependent businesses, like construction or pharmaceuticals; some of them, like RUMHE,<ref>RUMHE standing for Riqueza Urbana Madrileña Juan de Herrera, ''Hoja Oficial de Lunes'' 14.06.43, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=4&path=7148991&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> landed hefty contracts in prestigious locations, like the [[Gran Vía (Madrid)|Madrid Gran Vía]].<ref>''Hoja Oficial de Lunes'' 15.05.44, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=5&path=7149381&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In the 1950s he regularly featured in societé columns, attending aristocratic feasts related and unrelated to his own family. His political engagements were almost inexistent, except that he kept attending the Mártires de la Tradición sermons.<ref>''ABC'' 11.03.56, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1956/03/11/072.html here]</ref> This changed abruptly in the mid-1950s. In 1956 Florida was awarded [[Order of Civil Merit|Gran Cruz del Mérito Civil]], a very prestigious Francoist honor.<ref>''ABC'' 18.07.56, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1956/07/18/036.html here]</ref> In 1957 he was among 70-odd Carlists who concluded their longtime rapprochement with the [[Alfonsism|Alfonsist]] claimant, [[Infante Juan, Count of Barcelona|Don Juan]]. Satisfied that formal acceptance of Traditionalist principles rendered him fit for succession also from the Carlist perspective, they declared him the legitimate heir to the throne.<ref>Alcalá 2001, p. 139, Vallverdu 2014, p. 157, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 302</ref> Florida, one of the most distinguished of the so-called "Estorilos", entered the claimant’s Consejo Privado, the post retained until the end of his life.<ref>''ABC'' 02.04.93, available [http://hemeroteca.sevilla.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1993/04/02/100.html here]</ref>
Also as an octogenarian Florida kept attending social events, at times assuming unlikely roles; in 1962 he formed part of a jury at a female beauty contest.<ref>''ABC'' 25.05.62, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1962/05/25/003.html here]</ref> He remained engaged in religious activities, in particular in ranks of Hermandad de Caballeros de San Juan Bautista y Nuestra Señora de las Mercedes;<ref>''Hoja Oficial de Lunes'' 16.12.63, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=18&path=7150283&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> occasionally he presided over charity initiatives.<ref>''Hoja Oficial de Lunes'' 10.02.64, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=19&path=7150187&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Cautiously he kept admitting Traditionalist heritage; apart from cultural events like those dedicated to memory of Vázquez de Mella<ref>''ABC'' 27.02.58, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1958/02/27/041.html here]</ref> in the late 1960s he engaged in Hermandad de Cristo Rey de Requetés ex Combatientes, formally an organisation of Carlist Civil War combatants though in practice a Traditionalist bulwark in internal Carlist strife, aimed against a newly emergent [[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|progressist faction]];<ref>''ABC'' 11.06.67, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1967/06/11/089.html here]</ref> nothing indicates he was aware of the background and historians extensively discussing internal fragmentation of Carlism in the 1960s and 1970s do not mention his name.<ref>there are 3 PhD studies dealing with history of Carlism in the Francoist era, but except mentioning the 1957 Estoril episode, none of them mentions Florida, compare Martorell Pérez 2009, Ramón María Rodón Guinjoan, ''Invierno, primavera y otoño del carlismo (1939-1976)'' [PhD thesis Universitat Abat Oliba CEU], Barcelona 2015, Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''El naufragio de las ortodoxias. El carlismo, 1962–1977'', Pamplona 1997; {{ISBN|9788431315641}}</ref> Also in the late 1960s he kept cultivating the Juanista link;<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 07.05.67, available [http://hemeroteca-paginas.lavanguardia.com/LVE07/HEM/1967/05/07/LVG19670507-021.pdf here]</ref> in the 1970s he was noted only as attending weddings of his grandchildren.<ref>''ABC'' 07.06.72, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1972/06/07/057.html here], ''ABC'' 09.10.73, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1973/10/09/058.html here], ''ABC'' 25.10.73, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1973/10/25/055.html here]</ref>
